metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This case challenged multiple actions taken by the Department of Labor (DOL) to shut down the Job Co...

target:
This case challenged multiple actions taken by the Department of Labor (DOL) to shut down the Job Corps. The Job Corps trains and educates disadvantaged young people with additional career and technical instruction in order to assist them in attaining and retaining employment. Through career technical programs, career counseling, and apprenticeship programs, the Job Corps currently serves around 25,000 students.

On June 3, 2025, the plaintiffs, including national trade organizations and unions, companies with contracts with DOL relating to the Job Corps, Job Corps training center operators, and one current Job Corps student, filed suit in the District Court for the Southern District of New York. The plaintiffs challenged multiple actions taken by the DOL that the plaintiffs allege were intended to shut down the Job Corps, such as halting background checks as required for new students, canceling pending or outstanding Job Corps procurements, terminating the provision of internet services, drastically reducing DOL's budget for Job Corps, and canceling contracts with Job Corps center operators. The notices of contract cancellation directed the centers to send students home and to begin the shutdown of the centers.

Represented by private and in-house general counsel, the plaintiffs alleged that the DOL's actions exceeded its statutory authority, were contrary to law, and were arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act, and also that they were ultra vires and a violation of the Constitution's separation of powers. The plaintiffs asked the court to declare the defendants' actions unlawful, to enjoin the defendants from taking any steps to eliminate the Job Corps program, and to award the plaintiffs their court costs.

The plaintiffs also filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) on June 3. The case was assigned to District Judge Andrew L. Carter Jr., who granted the plaintiffs' motion on June 4. The court enjoined the defendants from giving effect to the elimination of the Job Corps program, or from taking any further actions to eliminate the program without Congressional authorization. The court also set a hearing for June 17 on the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. After the hearing, the court extended the TRO until June 25 and ordered the parties to file a status report on June 20.

The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 25. The court found that at least some of the plaintiffs had standing and that it had subject matter jurisdiction over the suit. Turning to the merits, the court found that the defendants' actions effectively closed, rather than terminated, the centers. Because the defendants had attempted to close the centers, the court held that they were required by statute to meet certain procedural requirements, which were not met here. Therefore, the court announced that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claim that the defendants had acted to contrary to law. As to the scope of the injunction, the court ruled that the injunction would be nationwide, but "will not supersede any contrary ruling by the court in the District of Columbia or any other federal circuit or district courts outside of the Second Circuit." Finally, the court rejected the defendants' request to immediately stay its ruling pending appeal since the request was not fully briefed at the time of its ruling.

On June 27, the court ordered the parties to file letters discussing how, if at all, the Supreme Court's decision in Casa Inc. v. Trump, which held that that universal injunctions "likely exceed the authority conferred [on District Courts] by the Judiciary Act," impacted the injunction issued by the court in this case. The plaintiffs filed their letter on June 30, arguing that Casa should have no effect in this case since (1) the injunction here was based on the APA, which was not addressed in the Supreme Court's decision; and (2) the injunction here was not overbroad since "setting aside Defendants’ decision to eliminate Job Corps is necessary to accord complete relief to the plaintiffs in this case." The defendants filed their letter on July 11, arguing that "this Court’s injunction is impermissibly overbroad because it extends beyond the plaintiffs to preclude the government from acting with respect to non-parties." The defendants also claimed that the injunction was not entered under the APA; instead, the court "granted a preliminary injunction under its traditional equitable authority, an authority that CASA made clear is limited to providing relief to the parties themselves."

On July 11 and July 17, two pro se individuals, students who were either attending or planning to attend Job Corps Centers, moved to intervene in the case.

After hearing oral argument on July 23, the court amended the preliminary injunction on July 24. The court ruled that the injunction applied "to the 31 centers covered by the Operator Plaintiffs and the 5 additional centers at which Plaintiff Transportation Communications Union/IAM provides training services." The court enjoined the defendants "from enforcing, implementing, maintaining or giving effect to the closure of the private Job Corps centers, including the stop work orders and termination and non-renewal notices delivered to Job Corps center operators starting May 29, 2025, from issuing, enforcing, implementing, maintaining or giving effect to any shutdown tasks, job terminations, or student removals; and from taking any further action to close any Job Corps Centers." The court ordered the parties to file a schedule on how to proceed in the case on August 1.

The case is ongoing.
target_paragraph: This case challenged multiple actions taken by the Department of Labor (DOL) to shut down the Job Corps. The Job Corps trains and educates disadvantaged young people with additional career and technical instruction in order to assist them in attaining and retaining employment. Through career technical programs, career counseling, and apprenticeship programs, the Job Corps currently serves around 25,000 students.

annotation.explanation: Defendant: Department of Labor (DOL)
Background: Job Corps serves disadvantaged youth with career and technical training, counseling, and apprenticeships, reaching about 25,000 students.

annotation.explanation: June 25–July 24, 2025: Preliminary injunction (nationwide, but not superseding any contrary ruling by courts outside the Second Circuit).

June 25: Court granted a preliminary injunction (nationwide but not superseding contrary rulings by courts outside the Second Circuit) and denied defendants' request to immediately stay the ruling pending appeal.

Preliminary injunction and factual findings: On June 25, the court found standing and jurisdiction, determined DOL’s actions effectively closed centers, noted statutory procedural requirements for closures were unmet, and concluded plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the contrary-to-law claim.
Initial injunction scope and stay: Nationwide scope with comity caveat; immediate stay request denied as not fully briefed.
Preliminary injunction granted June 25, 2025; nationwide in scope with limitation not to supersede contrary rulings outside the Second Circuit.
Defendants’ request to immediately stay the preliminary injunction pending appeal denied (not fully briefed).

June 25, 2025 Preliminary Injunction: Entered and made nationwide in scope, with a limitation that it will not supersede any contrary ruling by the District of Columbia court or any other federal courts outside the Second Circuit.
June 25, 2025 preliminary injunction: Nationwide in scope, with a carve-out that it will not supersede contrary rulings by the D.C. court or other federal courts outside the Second Circuit.

June 25, 2025: Preliminary injunction granted; court found standing and subject-matter jurisdiction; held plaintiffs likely to succeed because DOL effectively closed centers without required procedures; injunction nationwide but yields to contrary rulings outside the Second Circuit; request for immediate stay pending appeal denied.

Preliminary injunction granted on June 25, 2025; nationwide in scope with a proviso that it does not supersede contrary rulings by courts outside the Second Circuit; request to immediately stay pending appeal denied.

Through career technical programs, career counseling, and apprenticeship programs, the Job Corps currently serves around 25,000 students.

On June 3, 2025, the plaintiffs, including national trade organizations and unions, companies with contracts with DOL relating to the Job Corps, Job Corps training center operators, and one current Job Corps student, filed suit in the District Court for the Southern District of New York. The plaintiffs challenged multiple actions taken by the DOL that the plaintiffs allege were intended to shut down the Job Corps, such as halting background checks as required for new students, canceling pending or outstanding Job Corps procurements, terminating the provision of internet services, drastically reducing DOL's budget for Job Corps, and canceling contracts with Job Corps center operators. The notices of contract cancellation directed the centers to send students home and to begin the shutdown of the centers.

Represented by private and in-house general counsel, the plaintiffs alleged that the DOL's actions exceeded its statutory authority, were contrary to law, and were arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act, and also that they were ultra vires and a violation of the Constitution's separation of powers. The plaintiffs asked the court to declare the defendants' actions unlawful, to enjoin the defendants from taking any steps to eliminate the Job Corps program, and to award the plaintiffs their court costs.

The plaintiffs also filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) on June 3. The case was assigned to District Judge Andrew L. Carter Jr., who granted the plaintiffs' motion on June 4. The court enjoined the defendants from giving effect to the elimination of the Job Corps program, or from taking any further actions to eliminate the program without Congressional authorization. The court also set a hearing for June 17 on the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. After the hearing, the court extended the TRO until June 25 and ordered the parties to file a status report on June 20.

The court granted a preliminary injunction on June 25. The court found that at least some of the plaintiffs had standing and that it had subject matter jurisdiction over the suit. Turning to the merits, the court found that the defendants' actions effectively closed, rather than terminated, the centers. Because the defendants had attempted to close the centers, the court held that they were required by statute to meet certain procedural requirements, which were not met here. Therefore, the court announced that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claim that the defendants had acted to contrary to law. As to the scope of the injunction, the court ruled that the injunction would be nationwide, but "will not supersede any contrary ruling by the court in the District of Columbia or any other federal circuit or district courts outside of the Second Circuit." Finally, the court rejected the defendants' request to immediately stay its ruling pending appeal since the request was not fully briefed at the time of its ruling.

On June 27, the court ordered the parties to file letters discussing how, if at all, the Supreme Court's decision in Casa Inc. v. Trump, which held that that universal injunctions "likely exceed the authority conferred [on District Courts] by the Judiciary Act," impacted the injunction issued by the court in this case. The plaintiffs filed their letter on June 30, arguing that Casa should have no effect in this case since (1) the injunction here was based on the APA, which was not addressed in the Supreme Court's decision; and (2) the injunction here was not overbroad since "setting aside Defendants’ decision to eliminate Job Corps is necessary to accord complete relief to the plaintiffs in this case." The defendants filed their letter on July 11, arguing that "this Court’s injunction is impermissibly overbroad because it extends beyond the plaintiffs to preclude the government from acting with respect to non-parties." The defendants also claimed that the injunction was not entered under the APA; instead, the court "granted a preliminary injunction under its traditional equitable authority, an authority that CASA made clear is limited to providing relief to the parties themselves."

On July 11 and July 17, two pro se individuals, students who were either attending or planning to attend Job Corps Centers, moved to intervene in the case.

After hearing oral argument on July 23, the court amended the preliminary injunction on July 24. The court ruled that the injunction applied "to the 31 centers covered by the Operator Plaintiffs and the 5 additional centers at which Plaintiff Transportation Communications Union/IAM provides training services." The court enjoined the defendants "from enforcing, implementing, maintaining or giving effect to the closure of the private Job Corps centers, including the stop work orders and termination and non-renewal notices delivered to Job Corps center operators starting May 29, 2025, from issuing, enforcing, implementing, maintaining or giving effect to any shutdown tasks, job terminations, or student removals; and from taking any further action to close any Job Corps Centers." The court ordered the parties to file a schedule on how to proceed in the case on August 1.

The case is ongoing.
target_paragraph: On June 27, the court ordered the parties to file letters discussing how, if at all, the Supreme Court's decision in Casa Inc. v. Trump, which held that that universal injunctions "likely exceed the authority conferred [on District Courts] by the Judiciary Act," impacted the injunction issued by the court in this case. The plaintiffs filed their letter on June 30, arguing that Casa should have no effect in this case since (1) the injunction here was based on the APA, which was not addressed in the Supreme Court's decision; and (2) the injunction here was not overbroad since "setting aside Defendants’ decision to eliminate Job Corps is necessary to accord complete relief to the plaintiffs in this case." The defendants filed their letter on July 11, arguing that "this Court’s injunction is impermissibly overbroad because it extends beyond the plaintiffs to preclude the government from acting with respect to non-parties." The defendants also claimed that the injunction was not entered under the APA; instead, the court "granted a preliminary injunction under its traditional equitable authority, an authority that CASA made clear is limited to providing relief to the parties themselves."

annotation.explanation: Post-CASA briefing facts: Court solicited letters on CASA’s effect; plaintiffs argued APA basis and necessity for complete relief; defendants argued overbreadth and non-APA equitable basis.
Court-ordered supplemental briefing re Casa Inc. v. Trump: parties ordered June 27, 2025 to file letters; plaintiffs filed June 30, 2025; defendants filed July 11, 2025.

June 27, 2025: Court ordered supplemental letters on the impact of Casa Inc. v. Trump; plaintiffs filed June 30 arguing no effect; defendants filed July 11 arguing the injunction is overbroad and not under the APA.

annotation.explanation: From July 24, 2025 (ongoing): Amended preliminary injunction applying to the 31 Operator Plaintiffs’ centers and 5 additional TCU/IAM centers; enjoining enforcement or effect of closures, stop work orders, termination/non-renewal notices, shutdown tasks, job terminations, student removals, and any further action to close any Job Corps Centers.
Plaintiff: Transportation Communications Union/IAM (union providing training services at five Job Corps centers)

July 24: Court amended the preliminary injunction; applied it to the 31 centers covered by the Operator Plaintiffs and the 5 additional centers at which Plaintiff Transportation Communications Union/IAM provides training services; enjoined defendants from enforcing closures and related actions; ordered the parties to file a schedule on how to proceed by August 1.

Amended injunction scope and specifics: On July 24, the injunction was limited to 31 operator-plaintiff centers plus 5 TCU/IAM centers, and barred enforcement of closures, stop work orders, termination/non-renewal notices (delivered starting May 29, 2025), shutdown tasks, job terminations, student removals, or further closure actions.
Procedural status: Parties to propose schedule by August 1; case remains ongoing.

Amended preliminary injunction entered July 24, 2025 (after July 23 oral argument); applies to specified 36 centers; detailed prohibitions on closure-related actions; parties ordered to file schedule by August 1, 2025.

July 24, 2025 Amended Preliminary Injunction: Applies to 31 centers operated by Operator Plaintiffs and 5 additional centers with TCU/IAM training. Defendants are enjoined from: (a) enforcing, implementing, maintaining, or giving effect to the closure of private Job Corps centers, including stop work orders and termination/non-renewal notices issued starting May 29, 2025; (b) issuing, enforcing, implementing, maintaining, or giving effect to any shutdown tasks, job terminations, or student removals; and (c) taking any further action to close any Job Corps Centers.

July 24, 2025 amended preliminary injunction: Applies to the 31 centers of the Operator Plaintiffs and 5 additional centers where TCU/IAM provides training. Defendants are enjoined from enforcing, implementing, maintaining, or giving effect to closure of private Job Corps centers (including stop work orders and termination/non-renewal notices delivered starting May 29, 2025); from issuing or giving effect to any shutdown tasks, job terminations, or student removals; and from taking any further action to close any Job Corps Centers.

July 24, 2025 (after July 23 oral argument): Court amended preliminary injunction to apply to 31 operator-plaintiff centers plus 5 additional centers; enjoined various closure-related actions; ordered parties to file a schedule by August 1, 2025.

Preliminary injunction amended on July 24, 2025; applies to 31 operator-plaintiff centers and 5 additional TCU/IAM centers; enjoins enforcement of closures, stop work orders, termination and non-renewal notices, shutdown tasks, job terminations, student removals, and any further actions to close Job Corps centers.
